title: Magnavox Odyssey
description: The first home video game console in history. Used printed circuit cards to simulate games.

title: Odyssey 100
description: Successor model of the Magnavox with built-in games and simple black-and-white graphics. Helped popularize consoles in American homes.

title: Pong
description: Inspired by table tennis, Pong was a huge success in arcades and spawned many home versions.

title: Channel F
description: Created by Fairchild, it was the first console with interchangeable ROM cartridges and its own microprocessor.

title: TV Fun (Model 401)
description: Coleco’s console focused on Pong-style games, offering various built-in sports mode variations.

title: Atari VCS
description: Released as the Atari Video Computer System, it was the first widely popular console with interchangeable cartridges, becoming a landmark of the classic video game era.

title: Color TV Game 6
description: Nintendo’s first console, with six built-in Pong game variations. Marked the company’s entry into the home gaming market.

title: RCA Studio II
description: One of the first consoles to use interchangeable cartridges. Despite black-and-white graphics and built-in controls, it helped shape the early second generation.

title: APF-MP 1000
description: 8-bit console from APF with cartridges and color graphics. Tried to compete with the Atari 2600 but had limited market impact.

title: Bally Astrocade
description: Known for its advanced graphics for the time and built-in keyboard, the Astrocade offered cartridge games and BASIC programming.

title: Interton VC 4000
description: Second-generation German console with interchangeable cartridges and color graphics. Had its own game lineup and inspired many European clones.

title: Odyssey 2
description: Successor to the Magnavox Odyssey, it combined cartridge games, a built-in keyboard, and educational titles. Competed directly with the Atari 2600.

title: Telstar Colortron
description: Part of Coleco’s Telstar series, the Colortron featured Pong-style variations with color graphics and analog dials. One of the last before cartridges took over.

title: Intellivision
description: Released by Mattel, the Intellivision featured better graphics than the Atari 2600 and keypad controls. It pioneered sports and strategy gaming.

title: Cassette Vision
description: Developed by Epoch, it was the first Japanese console with interchangeable cartridges. It was popular in Japan until the Famicom overshadowed it.

title: CreatiVision
description: Developed by VTech, the CreatiVision combined console and computer features, with a built-in keyboard and cartridge games. Distributed under various names globally.
